description.raw:
This pull request addresses a problem in the fixed joint implementation in bullet that causes an unexpected rotation when a fixed joints is used with links that have inertia matrices with non-zero values on their off-diagonal. As the gif demonstrates, the box rotates about 45 degrees as soon as the simulation starts. This doesn’t happen when using any other physics engine.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/GgE7oqx/images/1976104576-fixed_joint_off_diagonal.gif)
‌

This PR replaces the use of `btHingeConstraint` with `btGeneric6DofSpring2Constraint` although it’s not clear why the `btHingeConstraint` wasn’t working in the first place.

## Update:

I ended up reverting back to using `btHingeConstraint`. It’s a much simpler fix this way. The initial offset had to be used for the joint limit constraints.
description.html:
This pull request addresses a problem in the fixed joint implementation in bullet that causes an unexpected rotation when a fixed joints is used with links that have inertia matrices with non-zero values on their off-diagonal. As the gif demonstrates, the box rotates about 45 degrees as soon as the simulation starts. This doesn’t happen when using any other physics engine.

‌

This PR replaces the use of btHingeConstraint with btGeneric6DofSpring2Constraint although it’s not clear why the btHingeConstraint wasn’t working in the first place.

Update:

I ended up reverting back to using btHingeConstraint. It’s a much simpler fix this way. The initial offset had to be used for the joint limit constraints.

title.raw: Bullet: Fixed joints and inertia matrices with non-zero values on their off-diagonal
